Award.AwardTitle: Student Travel Support for Verification, Model Checking, and Abstract Interpretation (VMCAI) Winter School 2020

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: This travel grant provides support for 15 US-based students to attend the 32nd Winter School on Verification, Model Checking, and Abstract Interpretation (VMCAI) to be held in New Orleans, January 2020. VMCAI, one of the premier conference in formal verification, provides a forum for researchers from the communities of Verification, Model Checking, and Abstract Interpretation, facilitating interaction, cross-fertilization, and advancement of hybrid methods that combine these and related areas. The VMCAI winter school will give students the knowledge required to enter the field and present them with some of the newer research directions in the field. Students have much to gain from attending winter school's learning state-of-the-art methodologies, being exposed to new research questions, and interacting with senior researchers in their chosen area of expertise.<br/><br/>This travel grant will enable career development and learning opportunities for US-based and/or US citizen graduate students. Attending conferences like the VMCAI winter school is an important component of graduate school education for our society's future computer science researchers. Students have the opportunity to discuss leading edge research with world-class researchers in formal methods, and establish networks, connections, and mentoring relationships that will serve them well during their research careers. This project aims at increasing the participation of students from underrepresented groups and those from smaller institutions of education, to provide them with equal opportunities, rather than leave them behind.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main objective of this award was to sponsor travel of approximately 20 US students to attend the 2nd Winter School on Verication, Model Checking, and Abstract Interpretation in January 2020. The winter school was affiliated with the 21st International Conference on Verication, Model Checking, and Abstract Interpretation (VMCAI 2020). VMCAI, one of the premier conferences in formal verification, provides a forum for researchers from the communities of Verification, Model Checking, and Abstract Interpretation, facilitating interaction, cross-fertilization, and advancement of hybrid methods that combine these and related areas. The VMCAI winter school gave students the knowledge required to enter the field and present them with some of the newer research directions in the field. Students had much to gain from attending winter school's learning state-of-the-art methodologies, being exposed to new research questions, and interacting with senior researchers in their chosen area of expertise.

After the winter school, we asked students to submit a small report on if this winter school was useful for them and how this grant help them. All their comments are given in the .PDF file submitted with the more detailed grant report. In general, we can see that all of the students said that this grant was significantly beneficial for their development as a researcher. Students were describing which talks and interactions were useful for their research, but also how much they appreciated spending time with other students working in similar fields. The only complaint was that the school was too dense: the students asked for a longer winter school but with the same amount of talks.

This award was always publicly advertised on the winter school's website. In addition, we put a call for participation on various mailing lists. Moreover, to increase visibility we contacted leading researchers in the field and informed them about this travel award, asking them to advertise it further. We asked each awardee to voluntarily identify themselves if they belong to any of the minority groups in the STEM field. Four students identified themselves as women.

 The grant covered travel costs, the winter school fee, meals, and shared accommodation. The awardees were reimbursed actual travel costs, not giving them a lump sum.  All the costs were reimbursed through Yale's Faculty Research Management services (FRMS), and in accordance with the NSF cost reimbursement policies.
